Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Patient Blood Management in Adult Cardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted by the Working Group on Cardiopulmonary Bypass and Extracorporeal Life Support of China National Center for Cardiovascular Quality Improvement.

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were adult patients undergoing cardiac surgery with CPB at participating hospitals in China.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a comprehensive PBM program, while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to establish evidence-based guidelines for patient blood management (PBM) in adult cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) to minimize blood loss and allogeneic transfusion.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of allogeneic blood transfusion, measured perioperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2023 and June 2023.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in allogeneic transfusion rates (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 10% to 20%; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 5% of the intervention group and 3% of the control group, with no severe events.

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by the China National Center for Cardiovascular Quality Improvement.
